div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William H. Ballou, January 25, 1922
div1.p:
2121 California St., N. W.
Bacteria?
, D. C.
January 25, 1922. /LC
Dr. William H. Ballou,
37 West 68th. Street, N. W.
New York, N. Y.
Dear Sir:

I have seen a page of the Sunday Edition of the Washington Times
containing part of a story by Dr. Ballou of the discovery by a Jap-
anese scientist--Dr. R. Koudo of the University of Illinois--of a
microorganism--Thelamia--species?--which he found efficient in destroy-
ing the larvae of mosquitoes--Culex pipiens and Anopheles punctipennis.

It is stated that Dr. Kudo's findings are published in the Jour-
nal of Morphology. I have been unable to find them in such numbers as
are on file in the libraries here, but all of them are not on file.

If you are the Dr. Ballou who wrote the above account, will you
kindly advise me of the number and date of the above Journal contain-
ing Dr. Kudo's article?
Very truly yours,

Address
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St, N. W.
Washington, D. C.

2121 California St., N. W.,
, D. C.
January 25, 1922. /LC
Dr. R. Kudo,
University of Illinois,
Dear Sir:

I have seen a page of the Sunday Edition of the Washington Times
containing part of a story by Dr. Ballou of the discovery by a Japan-
ese scientist--Dr. R. Koudo of the University of Illinois--of a micro-
organism-- Thelamia (species?), which he found efficient in destroy-
ing the larvae of mosquitoes--Culex pipiens and Anopheles punctipennis.

It is stated that Dr. Kudo's findings are published in the Jour-
nal of Morphology. I have been unable to find them in such numbers
as are on file in the libraries here, but all of them are not on file.

Will you kindly advise me of the number and date of the above
Journal containing the article to which Dr. Ballou alludes as I
should like very much to read it?
Very truly yours,

Address
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.

OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Brewton, ALA. Jan. 26, 1922. Dear Doctor Carter:

Your letter Jan. 23, enclosing that excellent account
of Murderers in Paris obversed by the Mosquito Murderers, received this
morning. I think I have the explanation of where those newspaper
articles got their inspiration. Received a letter from Professor Kudo
in which he makes no remark on the baterial article, but, in response to my
request, sends reprints on some recent work on Microsporidia. I had the
reference to the Microsporidia articles in Washington, but the numbers
of the Jl. of Morphology containing them were out. I think that the
newspapers got their information from the microsporidian, Thelohania magna
article, and glorified this very modest protozoan into the mosquito
bacterium. I send you the whole evidence enclosed. Please return when
convenient, since we have been interested in this same protozoan. Odd,
but while I was trying to find out about the bacterium of Kudo we were
taking notes on this same protozoan. We began to find it last Jan. near
Camilla, and collected it from time to time all during the season. In-
fected larvae would not pupate in the laboratory, so we tried to
propagate the thing to see if it could be made of any value in diminishing
breeding. It would not spread readily to other larvae. Besides, a small
pond near Camilla was well seeded with this parasite, as well as one
could hope to seed it artificially, yet this pond continued to be our
best collecting place during the whole season. Being without fish it
swarmed with Anopheles. We had the not at that time seen the article of
Kudo, but sent some specimens to Hegner at Baltimore, who thought them
Microsporidia. Mr. Komp found this or a very similar parasite this week
on Culex territans. We had previously found it only on Anopheles, crucians
and quads. I have written Prof. Kudo asking if he does not think the
newspaper articles came from his Thelohania.

Mr. Hayne, Theodore, is with me now, arrived two days ago. We have
a good field laboratory and have made a good start in the work. Mr. Komp
and I have been here since about the first of the month. This is a very
good region for studying the winter activities of mosquitoes, such a
great variety of woods and water. The job this month, after getting
laboratory established, has been to see what species are breeding in
winter-a continuation of the work of last winter in Camilla. We have
bred out here during the past three weeks about a thousand Anoph.
Only one quad, some scores of punct. but the great mass are crucians,
as was the case in Camilla last year. We shall repeat experiments of last
year in which we demonstrated eggs laying, hatching of eggs, a d roughly
the rate of development of larvae and pupae during winter conditions. We
will study the hibernation of adults, of course, as we did last winter,
and the prevalence of winter malaria for this region. One point, of course,
is to try to get eveidence on the question as to whether there is much
malaria transmission before the quad season. Quads occurred in ponds in
March last year, but breeding was not very marked until May.
We infected many cages artificially, crucians mostly, and kept them at
room temperature last spring. No sporozoites developed, or very few,
until warm weather. The whole thing, as you see, of course, is to get
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
2.
all possible information as to the seasonal incidence of malaria transmission
transmission, especially as regards the spring and early summer trans-
mission. Could one postpone the attack on Anopheles until midsummer, in
case funds were lacking for the whole season campaign, as they probably
would be for a rural community! Also, is there any hope of a successful
winter attack on Anopheles in this region, as has been often proposed for
Anopheles in northern Europe? I doubt if there is much hope for a region
like this, since there is so much winter breeding and hibernating (if there
is any real hibernating) adults are so widely scattered.

We have some material, observations and experiments, on the domestic,
animal and malaria problem for as conditions are in the South. The gist
of the results so far is that Anopheles here would about as soon bite
man as an animal-they may prefer animals if very convenient to bite
them, but they have lost little of their taste for human blood. We have
done two series of comparing human and animal baits. Also, if animals
must be housed in order to properly attract mosquitoes, they are not
going to be very attractive in this region. I think I have the most of the
literature on this subject, going back to the Italian observations of
nearly 20 years ago. I presume you have seen the last Roubaud article-
Bull. Soc. Path. Exot. XIV, 1921, 577. I am afraid we could not guage
the amount of malaria in any region of this country by counting the
quad's teeth!

Then, later in the summer, we may try the arsenic on a fairly large
scale in some region like S.E. Missouri, where the most of the breeding
is found in the large drainage ditches. We have also some unfinished
work on mosquito dispersal, which may have to be done in the rice region,
unless enough Anopheles can be found here.

We have been keeping several irons in the fire so as to fit the work
into varying conditions of drouth, cold, and the like. I think Mayne
will take up the punctipennis problem. I can think of no better way of
getting at this than to get out into the field in some region where
punct. is the only species and to follow observations on indigenous
malaria over several seasons.

I have troubled you with a rather long letter, since I should much
appreciate your counsel on any of our problems. Especially, do you think
a careful study of the seasonal incidence of the different species of
Anopheles and of malaria worth while? Winter activities is about all one
can study now, anyway, unless one should move further south where condi-
tions would not be typical for the South.
Respectfully yours,
M A Barber

My Univ. of Kans.correspondent could find no reference to
bacterial disease of mosquito larvae in J. Morph. back to 1917.
nor could I in Washington back 2 or 3 years.
